Title: N/A

reviewText: Someone please explain to me why amazon would let stand all these completely ignorant people "reviewing" a disc they haven't seen nor that they have any intention of purchasing.  The purpose of these amateur "reviews" is, one would think, to actually talk about the product, not what one wishes the product were.  So, to all those who've wasted everyone's time, please, go do something else than post your blather for the whole world to read.  Onto the set: The episodes included in this collection are great.  To the gentleman who complained about the quality - you obviously never saw the show when it aired - this DVD perfectly replicates what the show looked like.  The quality is top-notch - if they'd used a low bit rate as this guy suggests, NONE of it would look good.  I gotta tell you...  The extras are mostly wonderful - some of the interviews with the guests are so strange and wacky you wonder if we're being put on.  There are some very touching moments, too.  This is a wonderful set, and I recommend it highly.  It would be lovely to have full seasons, but for now, this will do nicely.
summary: A Great Set
Title: N/A

reviewText: I am extremely happy I bought this. Yes, it is completely unfortunate that episodes were cut, it really does not work well. For example,there were a series of shows in this complilation that were following the arc of Larry's marriage ,then suddenly, there is whole other chapter of his life. Choppy. I have the 1st season and being able to see each episode makes all the difference. I do hope the powers that be will release the full subsequent seasons.However! All is not lost, this compliation does feature good episodes, ( thank gd for the spiders and Carol Burnett!) but even more of a wonderful treat are the interviews!They are heartfelt interviews with the actors and actresses I have grown to love so much, and most are not conducted in the usual sit down way...Penny Johnson ( Beverly) is knock-out drop dead gorgeous, I mean she always was cute and charming and so so so talented, but how wonderful to see her "now", and Janeane Garofalo, cute and way too hard on herself! A lovely surprise, sort of bittersweet, by the darling Linda Doucett... Mary Lynn Rajskub now an exotic blonde... the cast members all had wonderful stories and memories. As for the men, it was terrific to see them all, Jeremy Piven ( and who knew he would be so divine in Entourage!?) , Wallace Langham, so deceptively chameleon in his role on the show!, Scott Thompson in the bathtub! Crazy fun interview bubbles and all. Great moments between Garry and Sharon Stone... I had always thought of her as a cold snob but if she was being "real" and it seemed she was, she is a warm, sweet lady now. And yes pretty. Great basketball interview with David Duchovney! and boxing with Alec Baldwin who is obviously still upset about his divorce... a split screen phone interview with Jon Stewart... and a tear-inducing heart full of love get together with the amazing Jeffrey Tambor and the very handsome and dashing- with a goatee-Rip Torn!And then there is Garry, so sweet and humble and kind, I felt I really got to see him as an artist , and as a very considerate man. I do not believe he did this compilation in order to squeeze his fans for money. I would like to think there were other ?legal ( as others on this site have said) issues which prevented the whole seasons from being released...but maybe I am being naive. Well, what ever the reason, this was a nice product and gave me hours of laughs and tears. I would say to all the fans, it is worth having.
summary: If you love Larry, if you love Garry!...get this , at least for the interviews...
Title: N/A

reviewText: Recognizing that the rabid fan will never be pleased by anything less than every episode, this is nonetheless a great package for the individual who is new to Gary Shandling, or for the viewer who wants to replace a collection of old tapes with a manageable and affordable DVD compilation. The special features are compendious and it is fascinating--and sometimes disquieting--to see and hear GS in uncomforable situations with former colleagues, girlfriends and 'the talent'. Altogether, this is a great 'middle of the road' purchase and one that should set a standard for 'auteur recollections'.
summary: A great place to start [or stop]

reviewText: Larry Sanders is classic comedy that is no longer shown on HBO due to the years since the series ended (1998 was its final year), and when it was on Bravo the episodes were never shown uncut due to censorship and time constraint issues. With the likelihood that so much time passes that it is finally decided that, due to its format, this show is so "nineties-centric" with all of its guest stars that it is too dated to be a success on DVD, I shall break down and buy this set and hope that, with my luck, seasons two through six promptly follow.The selection of episodes is pretty good, although they tend to be more Larry-centric and more focused on telling the story of the show than just the best possible selection of individual episodes. There are three episodes from season one in this set, so along with Season One which is being reissued, these two sets give us 33 of the 89 total episodes on DVD. There are a couple of episodes I consider essential that I was disappointed to see were omitted from the set. The first of these is "The Grand Opening" from season two, where Hank decides to open his "Hank's Look Around Cafe". The tables in the restaurant moved around so you had a different view every few minutes. Everyone knew it was a bad idea, but Hank wanted this so much that there was no dissuading him. When Larry is eating there, the tables creak and wobble, glasses fall over, and rolls fall off the table. It's absolutely hilarious classic Hank. To quote Artie, "That's great television, my friend."  The other episode I wished had been included was "Artie and Angie and Hank and Hercules" from Season 5. Besides the other subplots going on in this episode, Hank auditions to be the voice of Hercules in an animated feature. Hank is upset when he learns his voice is to be that of the village fool rather than the title character. Nobody else has actually listed the 23 included episodes, so I do that next:Season 1:1. "What Have You Done For Me Lately?" - featuring Robert Hays - The premiere episode that introduces the characters.Audio Commentary by Garry Shandling and writer Peter Tolan2. "The Spiders Episode" - featuring Carol Burnett and Jon Lovitz - Larry is afraid of spiders, and his scheduled guest is a naturalist who plans to bring some on the set.3. "The Hey Now Episode" - featuring Bob Saget, Earl Holliman, T. Bone Burnett, and Ray Combs - Hank faces Gary's ire when he falls asleep on the show.Season 2:4. "The List" - featuring Alec Baldwin, Ed Begley, Jr., and Daniel Baldwin - Gary is in the process of rekindling his romance with his ex-wife, but his suspicions about her romances since their break-up cause him to be jealous.5. "The Hankerciser 200" - Hank endorses an exercise device that has the capacity to injure people.6. "Life Behind Larry" - featuring Bobcat Goldthwait, David Letterman, Steven Wright, Kevin Nealon, Tom Snyder, and Richard Lewis - While everyone else is concerned about finding a host for a show that will follow Larry's in the late-night line-up, Larry is only interested in the possibility of him once again not winning an award for the show.Season 3:7. "Hank's Night in the Sun" - featuring George Wendt and Shadoe Stevens - Classic Hank. Hank fills in for Gary when he is sick. His insecurity makes him a big hit. Not realizing this, he goes on the next night full of confidence and strikes out.Audio Commentary by Garry Shandling and director Todd Holland8. "Office Romance" - featuring Bob Saget - Darlene decides to date both Phil and Gary, causing a clash of egos.9. "The Mr. Sharon Stone Show" - featuring Sharon Stone and Julianne Phillips - Larry's main concern with his dinner date with Sharon Stone is that she is more famous than he is.10. "Hank's Divorce" - featuring Joan Embery, Wayne Rogers, and Alex Trebek - Hank's wife announces she wants a divorce on their first wedding anniversary.Season 4:11. "Hank's Sex Tape" - featuring Henry Winkler, Norm MacDonald, and Jon Favreau - Hank is chosen as spokesperson for Florida Orange Juice partly based on his reputation as a clean-cut guy. However, a revealing videotape discovered by Phil looks set to ruin Hank's image.12. "I Was a Teenage " - featuring Brett Butler - Brett Butler thinks Paula is behaving strangely towards her because they once had a relationship. In fact, Paula's behavior is due to a serious medical worry.Season 5:13. "Everybody Loves Larry" - featuring David Duchovny, Elvis Costello, Jon Stewart, and Charles Nelson Reilly - Larry is concerned the network wants to make Jon Stewart a permanent guest host. Larry is also concerned that David Duchovny is attracted to him.14. "My Name is Asher Kingsley" - featuring Tom Poston and They Might Be Giants - Hank is intent in bringing his new found faith on the air with him. His religious fervor lessens, though, when he discovers his beautiful rabbi's interest in him is purely spiritual.15. "Ellen, or Isn't She?" - featuring Ellen DeGeneres (plus a deleted scene with Larry Miller) - Artie encourages Larry to quiz Ellen about her personal life on the air. However, an unplanned fling between Larry and Ellen makes this task an uncomfortable one.16. "Larry's New Love" - featuring Bruce Greenwood, Jeff Foxworthy, Daisy Fuentes, Warren Littlefield, and Paul Westerberg - Larry's new girlfriend wants to use her spot on Larry's show to launch her own career.Season 6:17. "Another List" - featuring Winona Ryder, Jon Stewart, and Smash Mouth - Once again, Larry feels threatened by Jon Stewart. However, this time he is afraid he is actually going to be replaced by Jon.18. "The Beginning of the End" - featuring Jon Stewart and Colin Hay - A creative consultant joins the show and completely changes the format. Meanwhile, Larry's agent is courting Jon Stewart and insinuating the show would be better off with Stewart as host.19. "Pilots and Pens Lost" - featuring Dave Chappelle, Bridget Fonda, and Jonathan Katz - Phil decides to write a pilot for another show. Artie loses a pen Larry gave him as a gift.20. "The Interview" - featuring Vince Vaughn, Jim Belushi, Ben Folds Five, Maureen O'Boyle, and David Spade - Larry does an interview for "Extra" while Mary Lou can't figure out how to tell Hank she has hit his car.21. "Adolf Hankler" - featuring Jon Stewart, Jason Alexander, Kristen Johnston, and the Wu Tang Clan - John Stewart fills in for Larry. Problems arise when he insists on doing a completely offensive comedy skit.22. "Back in Litigation" - featuring Illeana Douglas, Bruno Kirby, Ed Begley, Jr., and Drew Barrymore (plus a deleted scene with Michael Richards) - Larry is hesitant to have an actress on his show that he's dating. Brian considers an harassment suit. Hank shoots videos of celebrity guests wishing Larry well as the last show nears.23. "Flip - Parts I & II" - featuring Warren Beatty, Clint Black, Jim Carrey, David Duchovny, Greg Kinnear, Bruno Kirby, Tom Petty, Jon Stewart, Tim Allen, Carol Burnett, Ellen DeGeneres, Sean Penn, and Jerry Seinfeld (plus a deleted scene with Illeana Douglas) - Larry wants big stars for his final show, and thus decides to visit David Duchovny to solicit his attendance despite his unease over Duchovny's crush on him.
summary: A pretty good selection of episodes, but not enough Hank

reviewText: This is a terrific collection of episodes, deleted scenes and extras.  To begin with the show is terrific- witty, well-done, really some wonderful television.  The 3 stars- Shandling, Tambor and Torn are really good together- the timing and writing is top notch.  The guest stars and supporting cast add depth to the shows.  The DVD set is particularly impressive.  It is a great set of episodes- some of the best they did- I might have put in others but that is a minor complaint.  The extras are great on these 4 discs.  Nice set of deleted scenes and current interviews with a whole range of people associated with the show.  Most TV box sets are just not this well put together.  Someone organized this well and put in extras that are interesting- at least if you like the show.  The addition of original material for the DVD set really adds value to the set.  Anyone who appreciated the show should really enjoy this set.
summary: Clever- the right way to do a DVD set

reviewText: I am a relatively new fan of the Lary Sanders' Show and this was my first big introduction, so I found this collection hillarious. However, I would have much preferred  a deeper collection and not had the extra space on the DVD filled with so many guest star real life interviews, which frankly I skipped. But virtually all the shows are so original and the interplay between the charcters back stage made this show original, real life, funny entertainment.
summary: Many Great Episodes: I would Prefer More Shows than the Star Interviews

reviewText: I recalled the laughs I got from the Larry Sanders Show when it originally aired and looked forward to this DVD. Some of the special features are interesting, such as the breakfast with Sharon Stone. But, by and large, this DVD is a bit disappointing.

reviewText: Will this serve as the definitive Larry Sanders DVD set?  It will probably depend on the sales.  Much of what is here is wonderful.  The show itself is as fascinating and enjoyable as ever.  Hank Kingsley is one of the greatest creations ever, and one has to wonder how much someone like Ed McMahon, say, resembled him behind the scenes.  But even greater to me is the amazing Rip Torn as Artie, Larry's producer, mentor, protector, and father figure.  What a remarkable character!  I can count on Artie alone to make me bust out laughing five or six times an episode, and that beats even Homer Simpson!  I wish there was more commentary on the episodes in this set -- I find these discussions the most worthwhile.  Unfortunately there are also a number of conversations taped recently between Garry Shandling and a number of the shows' guest stars, and these are far less interesting.  Shandling himself calls them self-indulgent and not intended for public consumption, and he is right.  Still, there are some memorable moments.  Like Alex Baldwin demonstrating his anger and bulk in a boxing ring -- one prays for unfortunates who may have been intimately acquainted with either.  There is a tremendously tedious sequence with Tom Petty -- apparently both men enjoyed some herbal refreshment before the interlude, and they make our eyes droop as well.  Then there is the spectacle of Jerry Seinfeld having a cow because he can't find his favorite leather jacket.  Yes, citizens, even gazillionaires can get upset over such mundane matters, except that THEY have assistants they can interrogate to resolve these difficulties over their cell phones.  On the up side, Carol Burnett proves herself as sly and adept in her interview as she always was in physical comedy.  What a talent!  So, I am deducting one star for this potpourri of hit-and-miss extra material -- and the dreadful ultra-slim DVD cases.  BE VERY CAREFUL WHEN YOU REMOVE THE DVDS FROM THESE CASES!!!  Although I have handled hundreds of DVDs over the last five years, Disc 3 cracked almost in half when I tried to remove it from its case.  Fortunately Amazon was good enough to replace the set with a new one, but consider yourself forewarned...
summary: Not the Best Packaging

reviewText: I couldn't always get through this amazing show when it was on....because it was too real. I am serious folks, this is almost a reality show. I was working in film and TV when this was on and after a 72+ hour  work week, it was just too much like being at work and I couldn't take it.NOW, however, I may nostalgically bask in the wonderful neuroses, petty fights, unbelievable stupidity and amazing personalities and talent that was MY workplace as well as the fictional (but you'd never know it) one of the Larry Sanders Show.An amazing realization of the ol' "backstage" drama... er.... I mean comedy.GET IT!Now I'm waiting for "It's Gary Shandling's Show!"I would like to add, that...what am I? The National Archives? Do I need every episode made? No. They will be available without having to own them. But even if you do want to own them all, this DVD has great extras... that should be in your master archive anyway!
summary: I usta not be able to watch

reviewText: Maybe it is my Toshiba DVD player, but I don't think so.Unlike many of the negative reviews that were written BEFORE the DVD was released, mine is more timely and relevant.Love the show.  Every second of it.  But I believe my discs may be defective (or the compression is flawed).  I can't get some of the bonus features to play at all.  And I've had to skip two episodes entirely so far because of digital freeze early in the episodes.I've played THOUSANDS of DVDs on my player with no problems.  But I'm having serious problems with these Larry discs.  I'm tempted to believe it is a DVD pressing/manufacturing problem and not a problem with my player.Five stars for show content (yes, I know getting Season Sets would make people happier, but I'll take what I can get.  It has been close to 63 years since the other DVD release of this show, so I'm not too hopeful anymore).And if there is a TV show on DVD with better bonus features, I have yet to find it.But subtract two stars for the disc problems.
summary: Content versus technology.  Content loses.
Title: N/A

reviewText: I don't get all the fuss.  As a fan of the show in general (but not every ep/every season), this is the PERFECT set for me.  I've watched a bunch of eps, and am a fan.  But I tend to find the show pretty hit and miss.  Some I find insanely hilarious, and others eh, not so much.  Eps with laugh out loud humor the whole way, and eps with a smile and nod at something clever, or chuckles of agreement.  This has pretty much summed up my personal experience with this show.  And with that said, I don't WANT to buy the complete series...I don't want to buy a complete season.  Rather the best eps, a good compilation, with loads of features.Yes, there are obviously people that want complete seasons or nothing.  But there's a marketplace for both.  Occasional viewers will love this set.  Rabid fans are going to keep waiting.  Fine, but that doesn't make this set a bad buy for the occasional fan, nor is it a logical reason to rate this set lower.I'm a fan of Mad About You.  They released a few seasons, then stopped to roll out a compliation, and fans are still waiting for more complete seasons.  I didn't bash the compilation release.  I just didn't buy it, and continue to wait for complete seasons.  Fine.  I'm sure there are people that only wanted the Mad About You highlights and are thrilled with the compilation.That's how I feel about this set.  It's great for me, and for semi-fans like me who don't want to buy complete seasons knowing they like maybe half of the eps.  As for the rabid fans, just don't buy this.  I get it.  Wait for more complete seasons, but stop rating this set lower just because you're tired of waiting.  There are tons of us who aren't going to wait, and are thrilled with this.
summary: Perfect for the casual (not hardcore) fan

reviewText: Garry Shandling had a brilliant idea (what it's really like to do a talk show, onstage and backstage) and pulled it off brilliantly.The casting was perfect (Rip Torn in a delicious turn as Freddie De Cordova-like producer Artie); Jeffrey Tambor is perfection as solopsistic sidekick Hank Kingsley; Penny Johnson as Larry's superb, protective assistant, Beverly; and Garry Shandling's Larry Sanders.I used to work across the hall from Johnny Carson's Tonight Show, and I can tell you that The Larry Sanders Show is axACTly as late-night talk shows are with the following examples.1. Much of the show's action takes place in the hall2. Gossip in the make-up room3. Green room anxieties by the guests4. Insecurities of even the biggest names5. Larry Sanders' daily check of everything down to the cue cards6. The way the producer hovers over everything, smoothing irritated network execs and deftly handling all problems, with a genuine affection for his star.7. The petty jealousies between staff members.8. The blame for anything is always put on a staff member, usually the producer or an assistant and never the star.9. How the star always tries to get a leg over pretty guest stars.10.The vanity of the star and how he can't make love at home when the radio is on, and can only do it when his own show is on.There's so much more about this biting satire that I'd like to tell you, but you'd better get hold of a copy and see for yourself.
summary: Five Stars Are Not Enough

reviewText: Maybe I'm confused, but isn't the entire point of writing a review here to actually review the product and not simply act as if its a forum to complain about release practices of studios?  Personally, I don't think 90% of the reviews here should relate to either people begging others to buy it in hopes of more seasons on DVD, or angry rants about the greed of studios.  This is about the product itself.  There are dozens and dozens of shows that have released best of compilations, and none of them have this same freakish level of scrutiny.  Personally, this has some of my favorite episodes of the series, Hank's Sex tape alone is worth buying any DVD set.  But better yet there's tons and tons of special features on this show.  I'm going to buy it, not because I hope it will increase the chances of further seasons, but because I love the show, and want to see the features.  If you are "protesting" then maybe you should find a cause worthy of your time and energy, and not waste it on things this superficial.
summary: Why so much animosity?
Title: N/A

reviewText: I'm with those who think you should evaluate this set for what it is, not for what it's not.  You just have to accept that the business people are responsible for not issuing all six seasons complete, and then look at what Garry Shandling DOES deliver here.The Extras here are just about the best I've ever seen.  The only thing I'd say that remotely compares to this on a DVD of a TV series is what came with the first couple volumes of Seinfeld.  There are interviews with every significant cast member, as well as in person visits with Garry Shandling and a few cast members that reveal a lot. Shandling shares parts of his personal history with you--early stand-up, early Tonight Show footage.And some of the extras are extraordinary for the honesty and emotion they reveal (compare this to the too-cool to feel Seinfeld).  The combination of the interview with Linda Doucette and Garry's later visit with her was the first of the extras I viewed, and it was heart-breaking and illuminating.  The show and real life dovetailed there for a time with Garry and Linda in a way that didn't quite work out as they'd hoped.  But to see they still care for each other and have moved on gives us a window into both the show and its players.So we have some very personal stuff and some nuts-and-bolts behind the scenes stuff about writing, directing, casting, and producing the show, as well as some deleted scenes.  For me, the unused original ending on the series finale was wonderful and would have closed the show in a more satisfying way.  Great to see it on DVD and be able to decide for myself.It's hard to quibble with much when it comes to episode selection.  I went ahead and got season one complete, so I have ten more shows to watch.  Too bad the rest of the series will never come out, but don't blame Shandling--support him and his vision by buying "Not Just the Best of..." and watching these amazing extras.Finally, you just have to root for Garry/Larry to accept life's limitations, get married, and have a kid--he'd love it!  The real Garry, not the celebrity Larry, that is....
summary: Best Set of Extras I've Seen on DVD
Title: N/A

reviewText: I really want to dock this review one star over the extremely justified criticism of making this a "Not Just The Best Of" rather than "The Complete Second Season." Fans of the series bought that first volume. This should have been Volume 2. HBO knows that, of course, and doesn't care...so rather than punish the performers and creative team behind the show, let's just call these episodes what they are...5-star episodes.It would have been extremely easy for The Larry Sanders Show to overstay its welcome. The central premise of the show didn't lend itself to an indefinite array of guests and plot twists. It left right around the time it should have, and the final episode was jam-packed with greatness. For starters, Tom Petty...and, of course, Jeffrey "Hank" Tambor...and the always-amazing Rip Torn. The "weasels" in the cast remained weasels right up to the end...especially Jeremy Piven's cameo as fired head writer Jerry and Wallace Langham as head writer Phil. Langham's character always seemed to be the most premeditated, unfeeling, self-serving character on the show. Larry's smack-down when "Phil" asks for the R-A-Y letters from the "Larry" sign is worth the price of admission.Larry's agent Stevie Grant (Bob Odenkirk) gets caught in a backstage "snowstorm" while convincing up-and-coming Jon Stewart that he is destined to become "The Next Big Thing" (amazing how life imitates art, eh?)In theThe Larry Sanders Show - The Complete First SeasonDVD, Garry Shandling...in a "bonus" interview segment...discusses Johnny Carson's reaction to the show. He loved it, but said that he never felt the "behind the scenes" life was as "mean" as the Sanders show portrayed it. Whether that's the case or not, no one would have tuned into a weekly series about kind, loving and supportive TV people. We watched because of "Larry's" insecurities, his cowardice, his willingness to let "Artie" do his dirty work over and over and over again, the hardly transparent loathing and resentment "Hank" harbored toward "Larry" while kissing up to the tenth power......it was a five-star show, and now that it's off the air and HBO is making decisions about treating it like "merchandise," they are making less than 5-star decisions. That about sums it up.
summary: You can't argue with quality...

reviewText: I was a fan of the Larry Sanders Show back when I was in high school when everyone else was watching 90210 and thinking that was entertainment.  Perhaps one of the funniest shows that ever came to fruition, it is a shame that we will never see the complete season box set because of Shandling's legal battles.  Seeing it again as an adult makes me see it in a whole new light, as a precursor of sorts to reality TV, the future hit shows for HBO, and how insane people really are.I just loved everything about this show : the obvious neurosis of Larry and his coworkers, the backstabbing, the fighting and obnoxious behavior, and the hilarious melding of personalities.  I used to think this was just fiction, but as I age I see that it's really a reflection of working culture.  It doesn't matter if you work in television, a white collar office, or a machine shop, people are nuts!  Here you see how a bunch of barely functional people live in a fake world of the late night talk show.  And once the cameras go off, the claws come out!  Perhaps we would function better in the office if we had cameras on us at all times.  I have witnessed all of these things in so called "white collar jobs" as an adult and wonder why people can't behave themselves a bit better.The commentaries and star interviews on this disc are great and take me back to the days when this show was still on the air.  And my neurosises are even worse now!
summary: One of the greatest shows in TV history

reviewText: Look, I'd like full season sets of THE LARRY SANDERS show released too, but I've got news for you - the reason there aren't season sets of this show is because not enough people bought the first season. I got mine day of release and I'm getting this one DOR as well. I'd rather have a selection of the best episodes than not have them at all. Hell, I'd buy this set just for "Hanks' Birthday" and "Hank's Night In The Sun"! I'm not happy about buying episodes I already own as part of the first season set, but I think the rest are worth the investment. so stop your whining and get this so they'll see there's an audience for the rest of the shows.

reviewText: I'm not sure why they didn't release these in chronological, season order. They'll probably get to it at some point. Meanwhile, this is an interesting collection, especially the followup interviews Garry Shandling does with former guests on the show. I haven't been able to get through the whole set, but his Alec Baldwin tete a tete is revelatory, and his Sharon Stone summit of former real life lovers is uncomfortable in a good way. The actual visual quality of the 'Larry Sanders' episodes can vary a little bit. I'm not sure why they're not all HD perfect, but it's a small price for what you get.
summary: Quite unique

reviewText: I'm as negative as this edition as the rest of you. However, let's look at the bright side: The press release says there are 23 episodes (with one of them being an hour long), which is actually impressive for a box set. (Let's leave aside the fact that the first three episodes already appeared in the Season 1 set).  Also, they've padded it with extras. I'm sure Gary and company did a heck of a job making up for the incompetent release.I'm sure that the reasons for the failure to produce Season 2 is beyond Shandling's control. Let's not fault the show itself for the situation. (Btw, Gary, if you're out there, how about making a new Larry Sanders episode about the whole charade of trying to put out a boxed set of the Larry Sanders show--I'm sure whatever hassles the boxed set is going through would make for some high comedy).If I were to guess, the the problem is that Sony doesn't want to pay the fees to get clearance on the entertainer's performances during the show segments. The other possibility is that Sony wants to sell us the Larry Sanders show multiple times in various different editions (fans are assumed to be stupid enough to fall for it). The other possibility is that Gary Schandling genuinely wants to keep out of circulation episodes which are embarrassing to him or the people involved.  These episodes scratched a lot of raw nerves...romances, feuds with network executives, and celebrity excesses.(April 16 Update: Gary Shandling hints that they will be releasing additional seasons after this release.)For those wondering about Shandling's perspective on the boxed set release, here's a quotation from telephone interview with the Boston Globe reporter Mark Feeney on April 15, 2007:On the idea for the box set and why it took so long:Shandling: This started with Steve Moskow , the president of Sony Pictures Television. He had been asking me every year to put out the DVDs after they released the first season [in 2002]. The DVD market wasn't understood then and there was no extra marketing. So it was with his encouragement and enthusiasm that I said maybe this is the time to do it. The "best of" was basically his idea. That sounded right to me. It could let us look back historically and bring it back into the present, which is what those [guest] visits do.April 21 Update.  Seriously, I've been laughing my head off watching these episodes.  The extras were interesting, though I've only watched a few (given that the original show concept was a show-about-a-show). That said, I am confused by certain plot things I remember from the series--due partly to the random jumbo of episodes. For new fans, it won't be an issue, but for diehard fans, it will be confusing and dismaying. You find yourself wondering what was missing and why. What about Hank's restaurant and its grand opening? What happened to Garafalo's character? When I mentioned in a previous paragraph that the making-of-the-DVD would make a great episode in itself, I wasn't kidding.The extras have been fun enough (especially the one with one of the actors being interviewed while he was taking a bath).Watching the episodes with a new eye, I am struck by the cynical almost bittersweet qualities to the show. People were always lying to one another (and themselves); Artie was the only one to call the BS on everybody. The show did a great job at capturing the dynamics of the creative office: ironically even though Hank is the buffoon on the show, the Larry Sanders character is just as absorbed (he must have his massage chair, and he gets Artie to do his dirty work for him). Like the Office, these kinds of characters are not too far from the everyday types you meet in a regular dysfunctional office.
summary: look at the bright side

reviewText: . . . but if I were to quote Artie in the spider show, "Huge laughs. . .HUGE!,"  I'd have to, just to capture his passionate insincerity.  It would be 50/50, well 60/40, if I were considering the purchase now, with the Complete set due in November.  But I got it in May and no regrets.  Just terrific.  I've watched three of the four discs and I'm dragging my feet because I don't want to finish too soon.  Not only do the shows hold up but the extras are wonderful.  All these stars are egotistical but also self-aware, and used to talking intriguingly about themselves to friends and therapists.  Great stuff, whether it's phony baloney or utterly sincere, some performed in absurd situations (Garry sparring in a boxing gym with Alec Baldwin).  Even the Jon Stewart phone conversation, the slowest of the group, is worth watching.
summary: Not polite to write in caps. . .

reviewText: If it is a fact that this DVD owes its incompleteness to a battle over music rights, let me state the obvious: Nobody cares.  We want the show as originally aired, in order, nothing missing, and will accept no substitutes.  I need interviews with Penny Johnson and David Duchovny like I need a five-year vacation in Siberia.  Jeez, why not interview Robert Hays while you're at it? That'd REALLY make up for not shelling out the bucks to do this right. Yeah, I guess Sony Pictures couldn't find any loose change rolling around in that $2.5 BILLION they made in JUST THE LAST THREE MONTHS OF 2006.Do your job right, Sony.  Make us happy.  Everyone: Boycott this release.
summary: Like a Poke in the Eye

reviewText: I'm what you might call a Seinfeld-fanatic. I pretty much have thought of it as the pinnacle of TV comedy for years now and Larry David's Curb Your Enthusiasm came in a close second for the longest time.But you know what? That was before I watched The Larry Sanders Show. I never even knew of its existence up until a couple months ago and Garry Shandling was just some weird looking unknown comedian in my mind. Imagine my surprise when I learn that not only is Shandling very funny, but that Rip Torn and Jeffery Tambor are in the show as well...AND even funnier! By the end of this boxset I was eagerly looking forward to picking up Season 1 of the show. I was even thinking this show MIGHT be better (overall) than Seinfeld.Don't get me wrong though, it's not like this way of thinking happened instantly. In fact, at first glance, the show is kinda underwhelming. None of the characters are zany and goofy (even Hank Kingsley isn't a goofball idiot all the time) and it really isn't like any other comedy you've seen. It even does a better job of one-camera use than Arrested Development (a show that relies heavily on narration to create humor) and once you start to focus on the nuances of the show, you'll see that this was not some cheesy Friends or Will & Grace show that was thrown together two minutes before filming.The characters are great, the acting is dead-on, the jokes are hilarious and even though the show has a "Dramady" feel to it because of the off-screen documentary style of filming, you never get sappy "Full House" or "Friends" moments. This is a comedy series through and through and is one of the very best shows I have ever seen...and I've seen a lot.
summary: Talk About An Overlooked Series!
Title: N/A

reviewText: Worthy of more honors than it received, "The Larry Sanders Show" (1992-98) remains a television classic. The "Not Just the Best" DVD set includes 23 episodes plus extras ranging from deleted scenes to cast interviews. However, Garry Shandling's selection process may differ from yours. Since the groundbreaking "narcissitcom" spanned 89 episodes, this greatest-hits approach will not satisfy everyone. Fan favorites such as "Arthur After Hours" (a tour de force from Rip Torn) and "Off Camera" (highlighted by the Gene Siskel-John Ritter fight) are nowhere to be found, but a lesser episode like "Pilots and Pens Lost" somehow made the cut. As a result, the DVD sampler is recommended primarily for newcomers. Shandling's brilliant talk-show satire deserves to be released in its entirety - with no flipping!
summary: A Good Overview, But Wait for the Entire Series
Title: N/A

reviewText: First off, any fan of "The Larry Sanders Show" (or good TV in general) MUST buy this collection: it was put together by Shandling himself, and the extras, while not always interesting, at least show the care that Garry put into assembling this DVD and the importance that he attaches to the show.  Moreover, it won't be a strain on anyone's pocketbook, because even if the later seasons are eventually released (which is doubtful), it won't be for a while, so you won't be buying any more Larry Sanders product for months or years. And later DVD's may not contain these extras, which you really must have.Furthermore, the casual fan of "Larry Sanders" (like me) may not want to invest in all six seasons of the show (which aren't available anyway), so this set provides a great anthology of the show. I would argue that this set is like a greatest hits collection, with more than enough to satisfy the casual fan but of course not enough for the more serious one. Still, the serious fan needs this for the extras at least, which are really wonderful.The deleted scenes are among the best I've seen on any DVD, giving a great glimpse of how they shot the show and also providing moments as funny as any in the aired episodes. Check out especially the Duchovny interview with "Flip," Hank's interviews of celebrities (esp. Michael Richards) for Larry's last show, and any of the deleted scenes that feature Hank. There are some really funny moments.Now, for some of the problems with this set. For one, the extras feature the most uncomfortable celebrity exchanges I've ever seen, but they are fascinating (for the most part) for that very reason - just like the celebrity exchanges on the real show (but maybe not quite as interesting as those). The Jerry Seinfeld visit was the best I thought - a very funny and interesting conversation about television and acting.The biggest problem, though, is the selection of episodes, which aren't necessarily the best episodes or my favorite ones or yours, but it is a good sampling. Shandling picks episodes that showcase each supporting actor and that focus on the storyline of the show.Of the 23 episodes, 7 come from the last season. That's nearly a third of the total, and I don't think those are the funniest episodes. They simply tell the story of the show's demise, which could have been accomplished in fewer episodes. The show really peaked in seasons 2-4, and it would have been nice to have more of those episodes, especially more of Hank Kingsley.Yet, overall, this is a must buy for both the casual fan as well as the more serious one, so what are you waiting for? This isn't just the best of the Larry Sanders show, but much more than that - probably one of the best put together DVD's I've seen. Truly worth it.P.S. Everyone always talks about how funny The Larry Sanders Show is, and it is truly one of the funniest TV shows ever. But I think there is a darker side to it that goes fairly unremarked, as the show gives a very scathing portrait of showbiz. Most of the celebrities come across as a--holes, and I know that they're just playing a part, but still they are playing themselves. Since wedon't know celebrities personally, you might think they're something like how they appear on the LS show - not a good thing.Anyway, I always found the last season kind of depressing in that Larry is essentially forced out of his job. I mean, you want Larry to win - to beat the network (more smug a--holes), and that doesn't happen. So, The Larry Sanders Show is comedy, but comedy with a bite and I think it offers one of the darkest looks at show business and television.  You'll never look at talk shows the same way again.
summary: Essential for Casual as well as Serious Fans

reviewText: After waiting years for the second season, this melange appears.  Good God!DVDs are cheap to produce; a release with minimal extras (like the first season of this show)has most of its costs in packaging, and licensing of music.  If the owners of this show had any class, they'd do the right thing and release the balance of the shows--with or without extras.What drives these decisions to release is profit margin; if they can make $10 on worthless drivel (in a box, with extras!) but only $5 on a quality show with an audience slightly more sophisticated than your standard Nielsen family, they'll seldom or never get to the latter.DVDs have been around long enough; there's no excuse for the absence of Larry Sanders, It's Gary Shandling's Show, Fox's Tracey Ullman show, Duckman, Days and Nights of Molly Dodd, etc.  Not when the industry releases Three's Company, Starsky & Hutch, Gilligan's Island, Hee-Haw, Green Acres, A-Team, Beverly Hillbillies, Dukes of Hazzard, Hogan's Heroes, Baywatch...and then re-releases them for HD TV...(wait and see if I'm wrong).And for those who think that downrating this release is inappropriate, and that letters to Sony or elsewhere are the thing to do:  Trust me, anyone who is going to lay out the money for a set of DVDs isn't going to base her decision on the stars reflected on the review of this set on Amazon--she'll have already seen one or more shows, have an interest in Gary Shandling anyway, or take the time to read the reviews that explain the reason for having given the bad rating.  Buying this kind of slapdash product gives the person who green-lighted this release validation; and, I doubt that anyone who enjoys this show would want that to happen.
summary: No Class, just greed

reviewText: All these negative reviews are a little sad - these are people who have completely lost perspective on life. If you are compllaiing about a DVD box because it's not the complete season and cannot see the benefits of a lovingly prepared best-of with a whopping eight hours of great material prepared by the show's creator, you are lost. If you are a fan of comedy satire etc. Pick this up right now. The show has aged incredibly well. The performances, especially by Rip Torn and Jeffrey Tambor as Hank "Hey Now" Kinglsey, are sublime.  It's a bargain. Hey now!
summary: Ignore the DVDweebs-this is a must-own
